Don’t call variants “strains.” The popular press went bonkers with “new strain” when the first variants appeared, but the word has a specific meaning. A strain has a clearly different biological action. There were three strains of polio, and being infected with (or immunized against) one of them didn’t prevent infection by one of the others. Dengue can kill with infection by a different strain than the one a person has immunity to. So this isn’t a nit-pick. A strain is a specific thing. A variant is not a strain.

the description of Australia having 2,000 cases a week, with only a hundred or so a week until June IS COMPLETELY MISLEADING AND FALSE FOR THE LATTER.



Firstly, until June, we have had 10s of cases a week, not a hundred, and they were all almost exclusively in hotel quarantine. That's right, you cannot enter Australia unless you are an Australian resident or citizen and even then, only with a very valid reason from a very small list of exemptions. And then you have to spend two weeks in quarantine on arrival, at your own expense, with regular testing and a negative test on day 11-13 (varies from state to state). Until June, we only had rare cases of community transmission and they were all exclusively leaks from hotel quarantine (staff infected, or travellers infected from COVID positive travellers in other rooms, the latter because hotels generally have terrible ventilation, increasing the risk of infection. We need dedicated quarantine facilities [intense glare at the Federal government]). Whenever these leaks occurred, in Perth, Adelaide, Brisbane/Gold Coast, Darwin or Melbourne, these cities went into snap 3-5 hard lockdowns in response to small numbers of cases, or even single cases. This broke any chains of transmission and allowed contact tracers to exhaustively trace any and all contacts. The contact tracing here does both up- and downstream tracing, as well as 3-4 rings (primary/close contacts, their primary/close contacts, casual/secondary contacts, and sometimes casual/secondary contacts of the primary/close contacts). In my city (Perth) we had an outbreak that ended up being a cluster of six infections. We put around 3,000 contacts into home isolation for two weeks. Yes, 3,000 contacts for 6 infections. This model of snap lockdowns and contact tracing is the model that is used in Western Australia, Northern Territory, Queensland, South Australia, Victoria, the ACT and Tasmania.


Secondly, the large outbreak that started in June was mostly restricted to the Greater Sydney area. It was started by a limousine driver who was transporting international flight crews; the driver wasn't vaccinated or wearing a mask and was not required to under NSW regulations. Much to the chagrin of literally every other state and territory, the New South Wales state government was a firm opponent of using snap lockdowns, or lockdowns at all. Those 300-400 cases a day are mostly limited to the Greater Sydney area. The NSW government unfortunately reacted far too slowly and in a limited way, resulting in a spreading of the Delta variant. The lockdown restrictions in Sydney have only just changed to be as strict as those used in every other state and territory. That large outbreak in Sydney has seeded outbreaks in Melbourne (x2), Brisbane (x2), Adelaide (x1), Darwin (x1), the ACT (x1) and Perth (x1). It has now also started seeding outbreaks in rural NSW. In South Australia, Tasmania, the Northern Territory (until yesterday when they went into a snap lockdown due to seeding from NSW), Queensland and Western Australia, there is currently no community transmission and we live with very few restrictions. Long story short: the outbreak in Sydney was caused by a state government who refused to follow the proven techniques used by other states here.

If the Delta variant DOES have a shorter incubation period, that, ironically, may make it easier to contain.
For example, the reason why HIV is much more common than a virus like say, Ebola, is because HIV can lay dormant in a victim for years, before causing AIDS (during which time, they may spread it to many partners), whereas, a person who contracts Ebola, commonly dies in about two days (during which time, they may simply spread it to other members of their own household).
And while viruses are much more transmissible after the onset of symptoms, in the majority of cases, a virus is transmitted while the carrier is still asymptomatic.
Let's say, you catch the Strep from kissing your date.
But the virus is dormant for a day or two.
During which time, you share your Chapstick with a friend at school, and double-dip from the ice-cream container at home.
By the time you realize that you've got it, it's too late.
And by the time that they realize that THEY have it, it's too late for them, either.
But the most successful viruses are the ones which do not kill the host (the common cold being one of them).

A good video but in need of slight correction. None of the variants as yet qualify to be genetically far enough removed from the wild type of SARS-CoV-2 to be considered a different strain. Not even close. The reason for this is that variants of SARS-CoV-2 can only rely on mutation to emerge, and these take a long time and many mutations to alter the genetic make enough to be a distinct strain. This is because it is a single-strand RNA virus with moderate 'proof reading' involved during replication. Viruses which mutate quickly do not have that proof-reading capacity, such as HIV, or are what is known as a segmented-strand RNA virus, such as influenza. In a segmented virus, emergence of a new strain can happen instantly, through what is known as rearrangement. This can occur when a cell is concurrently infected with two different strains of the same virus. In the case of influenza, the RNA strand is divide into 8 segments. When dual infection of a cell occurs, replication can result in (for example) the 1st, 2nd, 4th and 8th segment from the first virus combining with the 3rd, 5th. 6th and 7th segment of the second virus, creating a new virus which is massively different to each it was derived from, which then would be a new strain. The is known as viral-rearrangement and. being a single-strand RNA virus, SARS-CoV-2 is not capable of this. While mutation alone can only cause tiny changes (probably about 0.2-0.4%) in the genetic make-up of a virus, rearrangement could see the new virus 20% or more distinct from the parent viruses. This is why new influenza strains appear continuously and why SARS-CoV-2 don't, and won't for quite some time.

Caveat about the study showing vaccinated people have same viral load as unvaccinated people: it's not really a random sample. It of course only included people who were known to be infected with covid. But if you got a confirmed case of covid, chances are you have plenty of virus inside of you for you to even get sick enough to go get tested positive; so  it doesn't really say much about how effective the vaccine is. If the vaccine prevented infection you would of course have 0 viral load but you're excluded from the study. And if the vaccine prevented you from having a symptomatic infection or severe infection you probably have less virus than average but you'd be less likely to bother to get tested than someone who had a severe case, so these people would be disproportionately unrepresented in the study.

There was a paper not long ago wondering (with data) about injected vaccines vs ones administered by nasal spray. Lots of respiratory virus vaccines are nasal sprays, so we have some related data and studies. Anyways, those nasal vaccines seem to trigger a protective response in the respiratory tract that injections don't. The hypothesis is that the respiratory tract response can better prevent infection or at least keep viral loads down. There's lots of philosophy and biochemistry I don't quite understand involved, but it seems to make sense.
So, something we might want to keep in mind for boosters farther down the road and future pandemics (there will be future pandemics)

It seems to me that people are uneducated about the KIND/TYPE of 'vaccination" the coronavirus vaccine actually is. This is not the typical vaccine you got as a kid for polio or measles. Those work by exposing your immune system to a dead, dormant, and or weakened version of the thing you needed to learn to fight off. And for those vaccines, once your immune system has been shown it and worked out how to stop it, your risk of ever getting that disease is slim to practically none.

Then you have your seasonal vaccines, like the flu shot. These work just like other vaccines, except that these kinds of diseases mutate and multiply fast, so even if you were vaccinated for a specific strain of the flu this year, by next year, that strain of flu will have mutated so much that your body will no longer have as effective a response against it as it did. Aside from there being many multiple strains already and not knowing which ones will be the most active that year, these kinds of vaccines are basically a booster, or rather like warmup for your immune system, prepping them for the most likely invaders for the time, so that if one is encountered, there is less of a chance for you to get sick.

This new coronavirus vaccine is an RNA vaccine. It works completely differently. This vaccine Isn't showing your immune system a "version" of the disease and causing you to go through a dry run for practice. Its hardcoding some of your cells with the instructions necessary to fight off the invaders if they are spotted. Instead of seeing the disease and making antibodies in response to the invaders, the cells already know how to defend and are just waiting for the signal to start doing whatever it is they now know how to do.

Because of that distinction, its entirely possible to become infected with the disease when the RNA method is used. The body, most likely, hasn't ever actually made any antibodies yet because in theory, If none of the things the new instructions say to look out for ever appear in the body, then the instructions relayed to your cells by the RNA vaccine never get used. AND it takes a little time for your body to ramp up making all those things anyway.

Since your immune system stays 'alert' for a time after encountering an invader, The first type of vaccine rallies the troops already, in hopes of stopping the wall breach in the first place, but if the wall is breached, its still pretty bad. The RNA vaccine on the other hand has no walls at all. it hasn't rallied any specialized troops. But whenever that specific invader DOES show up, the cells already have defenses and know what to do, and get to work immediately, for a milder sickness experience overall. at least thats how i understand it.

I broadly agree with all of this, though I think maybe there's an important detail that should maybe have been mentioned starting at around 5:00. Taking as a given the unknown question of how much cycle threshold values correlate to competent viral load, there are indeed some preprints out that show similar cycle threshold values between vaccinated and unvaccinated individuals...at the very early stages of the infection. But at least one goes on to measure that day by day throughout the course of the illness, and CT values in vaccinated individuals drop much faster than the values in unvaccinated individuals, starting around day 5 of infection. If indeed CT values correlate to viral load, that suggests that the period in which the risk of transmission from delta-infected vaccinated people is equal to that of unvaccinated people is likely much shorter as well.

If you'd like to see the preprint I'm referring to for yourself, it is "Virological and serological kinetics of SARS-CoV-2 Delta variant vaccine-breakthrough infections: a multi-center cohort study", first author Po Ying Chia, and figure 1 on page 16 shows it most clearly. I'll give a shout out to This Week in Virology, which is a bunch of virologists talking shop, who I'm paraphrasing this objection from, and who in episode 789 did a rundown on delta and this paper.

Regardless of politics in Australia, there has been a big difference between what allowed us to successfully eliminate COVID-19 several times, and it slowly getting out of control now.

The previous times there was an outbreak, it was met with a statewide lockdown (mostly in Victoria), with significant blanket restrictions. This included not travelling more than 5km from your home, no visitors, no leaving the home unless its for getting supplies or if you're an essential worker (all of which were clearly communicated, documented and enforced with local police). Masks were also mandated indoors and outdoors.

In the current outbreak, it was in a different state (New South Wales), which has a different process on how they managed outbreaks, and it seems it was inadequate to manage the spread of the Delta variant. Instead of locking down the whole state, they initially put in light restrictions, then when things worsened, locked down local areas. This means that cases are bleeding through locked down regions into other areas, causing more spread in areas that aren't locked down. It was also a problem that during these lockdowns, there was a lot of uncertainty on what they considered reasons to leave the home. The government also didn't mandate masks, which meant (Anecdotally) about half the population didn't bother to wear them.

The current research from health experts in Australia seem to indicate that the Delta variant moves too quickly to be controlled with half measures. Hard, fast lockdowns over a wider population seems to be an effective tool to control and eliminate the Delta variant until a population is vaccinated. Unfortunately, the state government in charge of this outbreak seems unwilling to do this.

On the more political side of things, it hasn't helped that the NSW premier has been vocally critical of the lockdowns in Victoria last year, which has been supported by the right wing media. Comments calling the Victorian Premier a "Dictator", for his lockdowns, seem to have created a culture of ambivalence within the NSW population. This also meant that the NSW premier has painted herself into a corner, as her voter base is now deeply resistant to lockdowns, even though they are now necessary to control the spread. This, combined with the unclear communication, has lead to the current outbreak being very different from past outbreaks.

So that's why Australia is struggling more now than before. Its not entirely due to Delta, but more around a different procedure which has proven inadequate at eliminating the Delta variant where our previous procedure has succeeded.

As somebody that works in the contact tracing in a country where the Delta variant has now become the strain that causes the most positive cases (Belgium) , I can confirm that (from my experience) the effects on vaccinated people are not too different from previous variants. It does however cause symptoms more easily (amongst the unvaccinated and particularly in addition to previously, the unvaccinated younger people [ 18-35 ] as they seemed much less likely to be very symptomatic in the past).

The most important thing for you to do is whether you have or haven't been vaccinated is to contact your gp asap when you start to develop symptoms to have a PCR test performed. Or if they're not available you can get an antigen test at most pharmacies. That's the most effective way of stopping the spread.
The symptoms we 'look for' in people that might be positive and are seen as HRC(high risk contacts = people that were in contact with a positive person during their contagious period) are:
-cough
-loss of taste/smell (though indicative a very rare symptom)
-trouble breathing/pressure on chest
-runny nose
-soar throat
-headache
-muscle/joint pain
-diarrhea
-lack of energy (tired)
-nauseousness
-throwing up

Try to avoid contact with people and certainly those outside of your in-home family and look to get tested asap as well. better safe than sorry. If your gp isn't available try to get tested at a pharmacy, it won't be a PCR test (which is 100% the most accurate and effective as it is super sensitive) but most likely an antigen test. self tests can be good but false negatives happen so often. even positive people that do one for 'fun' (weird I know) will sometimes call because they tested negative on it. so even if you test negative on a self test and your symptoms are still there, contact your gp.
